title: Israel-Iran live updates: Trump demands Iran’s ‘unconditional surrender’ as strikes continue
description: Israel and Iran continue trading strikes as President Donald Trump gathered his top security advisers and the U.S. military increased firepower in the Middle East.
author: Frances Vinall, Abbie Cheeseman, Annabelle Timsit, Angie Orellana Hernandez, Michael Birnbaum
byline: Frances Vinall, Abbie Cheeseman, Annabelle Timsit, Angie Orellana Hernandez, Michael Birnbaum, Leo Sands, Lior Soroka, Mikhail Klimentov, Natalie Allison, Alon Rom, Sammy Westfall, Scott Clement, Karen DeYoung, Elahe Izadi, Brianna Tucker, Gerry Shih, Susannah George, Evan Hill, Heidi Levine, Adam Taylor, Joshua Yang, Mohamad El Chamaa, Kate Brady, Nilo Tabrizy, Patrick Svitek, Yeganeh Torbati, Kareem Fahim, Dan Lamothe, Abigail Hauslohner, Natalia Abbakumova, Jintak Han, Cat Zakrzewski, Amanda Coletta, Kelsey Ables
excerpt: Israel and Iran continue trading strikes as President Donald Trump gathered his top security advisers and the U.S. military increased firepower in the Middle East.
text: Sirens and loud explosions could be heard in Tel Aviv on Tuesday night, just hours after President Donald Trump gathered his top security advisers at the White House to discuss the prospect of U.S. involvement in the conflict between Israel and Iran. “He may decide he needs to take further action to end Iranian enrichment,” Vice President JD Vance said in a post Tuesday on X. In posts on social media, Trump demanded “unconditional surrender” from Iran and said that the United States knows where Iran’s supreme leader is but won’t kill him, “at least not for now.”What else to know on the fifth day of Israel-Iran strikesReturn to menuA U.S. attack on Iran could have major consequences for Donald Trump’s presidency and the region. Trump left the G-7 summit in Canada a day early Monday to decide whether to join Israel in an effort to destroy Iran’s key underground nuclear facilities — or go in a different direction by engaging in last-minute diplomacy with Tehran in a bid to impair its ability to build a nuclear weapon, U.S. officials said. Trump told reporters on Air Force One early Tuesday that he was “looking for better than a ceasefire” and wants “a real end” to Iran’s nuclear program.U.S. officials told The Washington Post late Monday that the Pentagon is expanding its military presence in the Middle East to increase the options available to commanders, should U.S. assets in the region face a direct threat.Iran fired about 30 missiles toward central Israel on Tuesday morning, injuring at least 12 people, according to Israel’s military and emergency services. Tehran claimed it inflicted strategic damage. Nadav Shoshani, a spokesman for the Israel Defense Forces, told The Post that Iran’s overnight attacks were the “least impactful night … since the beginning of this operation.”Iranian media reported explosions and heavy air defense fire in Tehran and explosions in the northwestern city of Tabriz. On Tuesday afternoon, Iran’s military announced attacks against Israel involving hundreds of drones and “new and advanced weapons” that it said will “intensify in the coming hours,” according to statements published by state media.Live coverage contributors 34Return to menuThe Israeli air force is conducting strikes on Tehran, the Israeli military announced Tuesday evening. Earlier Tuesday, Israel Defense Forces spokesman Avichay Adraee issued an evacuation warning for District 18 of Tehran.Trump spoke with Netanyahu on Tuesday, White House official saysReturn to menuPresident Donald Trump spoke with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday, according to a White House official who was not authorized to speak publicly.Trump, who returned to Washington in the morning after leaving the Group of Seven summit in Canada a day early, has spent the day at the White House consulting with his advisers and national security team amid the ongoing exchange of missile fire between Israel and Iran.Return to menuSirens sounded across Israel a second time early Wednesday local time, with the Israel Defense Forces warning again of missiles on their way to Israel from Iran. Loud explosions could be heard in Tel Aviv as the IDF said it was working to intercept the Iranian missiles.Return to menuNo casualties have been reported after an Iranian strike on Israel early Wednesday local time, said a spokesperson for Magen David Adom, the country’s emergency services.Meanwhile, reports of multiple fires around the country had been received by Israel’s Fire and Rescue Authority, said a spokesperson for the organization.In inaugural address, Trump said U.S. measure of success is ‘the wars we never get into’Return to menuAs President Donald Trump weighs U.S. military involvement in Iran, several of his top allies, including conservative pundit Tucker Carlson, have urged Trump to stay out of the war — with some pointing to his promise of being an anti-war president.“We will measure our success not only by the battles we win but also by the wars that we end — and perhaps most importantly, the wars we never get into,” Trump said in his inaugural address in January.Return to menuIsraeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called for nothing short of “total victory” in Israel’s conflicts with Hamas and Iran in an interview with Israel’s Channel 14 news. He said a “different Middle East” would emerge from the aftermath.Netanyahu said the operation to strike Iran was planned over the past three months and that his directive was to “go after the scientists.”“The scientists had to go, because the nuclear program had to go,” he said. “But I also said we must strike the missiles.”Americans, Trump voters oppose military involvement in Iran, poll findsReturn to menuAn Economist-YouGov poll released Tuesday found little appetite for U.S. military involvement in fighting between Israel and Iran. A 60 percent majority said the U.S. military should not “get involved in the conflict between Israel and Iran,” while 16 percent said it should get involved and 24 percent were not sure. Among those who voted for Trump in last year’s election, 53 percent opposed military involvement while 19 percent supported it.Return to menuThe Israeli military warned early Wednesday local time that it had identified missiles inbound from Iran, and called on the public to seek shelter. Sirens and explosions could be heard in Tel Aviv.Israeli officials call destruction of Fordow nuclear site in Iran a key military goalReturn to menuIn remarks to Israeli media Tuesday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and National Security Adviser Tzachi Hanegbi insisted that the destruction of Iran’s underground nuclear fuel enrichment site, Fordow, is crucial to the country’s military aims.Return to menuMajed Al-Ansari, a spokesman for Qatar’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs, condemned the targeting of nuclear and energy facilities in the conflict between Israel and Iran. He warned it would have “significant repercussions and impacts on global energy markets and regional security in general, especially with regard to the waters of the Gulf, on which we depend not only as a source of water in the region, but as a source of global energy.”Qatar is among the gulf states trying to de-escalate fighting between Iran and Israel, The Washington Post reported on Monday.Post Reports podcast: A major turning point in the Israel-Iran conflictReturn to menuPodcast episodeIsrael and Iran have been exchanging attacks since Friday, leaving more than 20 people dead in Israel and more than 200 dead in Iran. On today’s episode of Post Reports, reporter Yeganeh Torbati speaks to host Elahe Izadi about why Israel chose this moment to launch strikes against Iran, whether Iran’s government could fall, and whether the U.S. and President Donald Trump will get involved.Trump ‘perfectly within his right’ on Iran actions, Thune saysReturn to menuSenate Majority Leader John Thune (R-South Dakota) backed President Donald Trump and his actions toward Iran, saying the president is “perfectly within his authority” as the U.S. military amassed its forces in the Middle East amid ongoing strikes between Israel and Iran.“I think he’s perfectly within his right to do what he’s done so far,” Thune told reporters Tuesday when asked whether the Trump administration will need congressional approval to potentially strike Iran.Israel-Iran conflict could last only as long as their missiles hold outReturn to menuThe intensity of Iran’s barrages appears to be sharply dropping. After firing more than 150 missiles on the first night of the conflict, Friday, Iran fired a barrage of just 10 on Tuesday afternoon. Even so, Israeli analysts caution that more than half of Iran’s arsenal remains intact, and an unknown quantity of missiles may be hidden in underground depots.This is an excerpt from a full story.In photos: Israeli hospital treats patient wounded in Iranian strikesReturn to menuNardeen Rabi Gharaba, a Palestinian citizen of Israel and an intensive care nurse, treats a critically wounded female patient at Rabin Medical Center in Petah Tikva, Israel, on Tuesday. The woman was injured when an Iranian missile struck a high-rise residential building on Monday.The hospital moved 400 beds to a protected underground facility in a parking garage amid ongoing strikes between Israel and Iran.State Department sets up task force to support U.S. citizens in Israel and broader regionReturn to menuThe State Department announced Tuesday that it had set up a task force to help U.S. citizens in Israel and the broader region impacted by the ongoing conflict with Iran.The new task force is primarily designed to provide information to U.S. citizens and diplomatic personnel. Officials said that they did not have any plans for evacuations but did not rule out that they could come at a later point.Return to menuIranian state media told Iranians to delete WhatsApp from their phones, alleging without evidence that WhatsApp was forwarding data to Israel. “We’re concerned these false reports will be an excuse for our services to be blocked at a time when people need them the most,” said WhatsApp in a statement. “We do not provide bulk information to any government.”Return to menuThe Israeli military launched 60 fighter jets Tuesday aimed at destroying Iranian missile launchers that targeted Israel, Brig. Gen. Effie Defrin, Israel’s military spokesman, said in a media briefing Tuesday night.Defrin said that Israeli jets struck Iranian launchers in western Iran.Commercial airspace in Middle East disrupted by Iran-Israel conflictReturn to menuBEIRUT — As Iran and Israel continue to trade fire for the fifth day, several Middle Eastern countries whose airspace lies between the two arch foes have had flights interrupted and citizens put in danger. The affected governments have been left to scramble for ways to stay out of the conflict.Both Iran and Israel have used other countries’ airspace to mount attacks on each other. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu boasted Monday that Israel had “paved an aerial highway to Tehran.”Return to menuGerman Chancellor Friedrich Merz expressed gratitude for Israel’s attack on Iran in televised remarks on the sidelines of the G-7 summit Tuesday, saying Israel was doing “the dirty work … for all of us.”“We are also affected by this regime,” Merz added. “This mullah regime has brought death and destruction to the world.”Merz said Iran’s return to the negotiating table would preclude the need for further military intervention. “If not, then the complete destruction of the Iranian nuclear weapon program is possibly on the table,” he said.Return to menuGermany will assist its nationals in leaving Israel if they choose, the German foreign minister said Tuesday. Israel closed its airspace to civilian traffic at the beginning of its strikes against Iran, stranding foreign nationals within Israel and Israeli citizens overseas.The U.S. Embassy said Monday it could not directly assist with evacuations, though it did not explicitly urge Americans to leave Israel.Israel’s land borders with Jordan and Egypt remain open.Satellite images show damage to petroleum and oil storage tanks in IranReturn to menuSatellite imagery captured by Planet Labs on Monday shows multiple storage tanks housing petroleum products that were destroyed overnight in Shahran, a neighborhood in the northwest part of Tehran.“The aim of this was to cause fuel shortages and power outages,” said Samir Madani, a co-founder of TankerTrackers.com, which tracks and reports shipments and storage of crude oil.Trump: U.S. knows where Iran leader is but won’t kill him, ‘at least not for now’Return to menuPresident Donald Trump ratcheted up tensions with Iran on Tuesday, claiming the United States knows the location of the country’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, but is not looking to assassinate him — for the time being.Trump made the comments in a social media post, one of several in recent hours that marked an increasingly hostile posture toward Iran as Trump weighs a larger U.S. role in the Israel-Iran conflict.Return to menuVice President JD Vance is looking to reassure supporters of President Donald Trump who are skeptical of foreign intervention as the president weighs a larger U.S. role in the Iran-Israel conflict.In a lengthy X post, Vance praised Trump for showing “remarkable restraint” so far and suggested his supporters should trust that he will prioritize U.S. interests in whatever he does.“He may decide he needs to take further action to end Iranian enrichment,” Vance wrote. “That decision ultimately belongs to the president. And of course, people are right to be worried about foreign entanglement after the last 25 years of idiotic foreign policy.”Return to menuPresident Donald Trump said Iran was “very close”to having a nuclear weapon on June 17 while taking questions from reporters on Air Force One. (Video: The Washington Post)After seeing President Donald Trump’s tweet calling for the evacuation of Tehran, one man said he left the city around midday Tuesday.The man, who spoke on the condition of anonymity for fear of reprisal, said it was impossible to exchange money electronically or withdraw money from banks. He said merchants raised prices for food and supplies. Gas station lines were incredibly long, and he waited three hours to fill his car up.Return to menuDowntown Tehran began to empty on June 17, following a call by President Donald Trump for the immediate evacuation of the Iranian capital. (Video: AP)Long lines of cars waited at Tehran’s gas stations as the city’s downtown began to empty on Tuesday. The mass departures followed President Donald Trump’s Truth Social post saying that “everyone should immediately evacuate Tehran” in the early hours of the Iranian morning that day.Return to menuOnly the U.S. has the extremely heavy “bunker-buster” bombs believed capable of penetrating Iran’s most sophisticated nuclear facilities, which are buried under mountains. If President Donald Trump decides to join Israel in attacking Iran, he would draw Washington deeply into a war he has said would be devastating and that he has wanted to avoid. An attack risks splitting his political coalition, since the Republican Party is divided between those who believe in sharply pulling back from international conflicts and hawks who have long warned that Iran is a menace. The U.S. military has been moving equipment to the Middle East that would help facilitate a broader attack.The young Iranian poet who lost her life in an Israeli strikeReturn to menuShe dreamed of seeing the band Coldplay live in concert. She loved trying new foods and was learning Italian. She wrote poetry constantly and shared it with friends and family. She was so proud of having summited Iran’s highest peak, Mount Damavand, that she made sure to mention that fact to everyone she met.She was, as her friends described in phone interviews and text messages this week, as bright and full of life as the sunflowers that she adored.This is an excerpt from a full story.Return to menuTehran criticized Group of Seven leaders Tuesday for their statement on the fighting between Israel and Iran, saying its language “disregarded” Israeli aggression. Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Esmaeil Baqaei said Israeli strikes have killed “hundreds of innocent people” and destroyed public infrastructure and homes. Baqaei described Iranian strikes against Israel as actions taken in self-defense.Families in Tehran feel rising panic amid Israeli strikesReturn to menuSoudeh, 29, an accountant in Tehran, said she has a 10-month-old baby and had not been able to sleep from stress amid Israeli strikes.At one point she heard a loud blast in her alley. The buildings in her neighborhood are close together, and though her own wasn’t hit, she was worried about another collapsing, she said, speaking on the condition that she be identified only by her first name, for fear of reprisal.Arab gulf states work to contain fallout from Israel’s attack on IranReturn to menuIranian officials have told mediators that they are open to resuming nuclear talks with the United States, but they first want Israel to stop its attacks, two officials briefed on the matter said Monday, as fighting between the regional archrivals continued for a fourth day.This is an excerpt from a full story.IAEA: Israeli strike may have made ‘direct impact’ on Natanz nuclear site’s undergroundReturn to menuBEIRUT — Israeli strikes appear to have made “direct impacts” on the underground section of Iran’s Natanz nuclear enrichment site, the United Nations nuclear watchdog said Tuesday, in its first assessment that the centrifuge halls buried deep underground may have been damaged.Return to menuIf the United States were to get militarily involved in the conflict between Iran and Israel, European Union foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas said Tuesday, it will “definitely drag the region into a broader conflict.” Kallas said she spoke with Secretary of State Marco Rubio and “he emphasized that it’s also not in their interest to be drawn into this conflict.”Return to menuAll doctors and nurses in Iran had their leave canceled and were asked to remain in medical centers, Iran’s semiofficial Mehr news reported Tuesday, in the face of mass casualty incidents it said are resulting from the conflict. Iran said Sunday that Israeli strikes had killed at least 224 people and wounded hundreds of others and has not provided an updated toll since. Human rights groups in the country say the Health Ministry’s numbers are a significant undercount.Return to menuIsrael has been intercepting Iranian drones on an “hourly basis,” an Israeli military official told reporters in a news briefing Tuesday. He spoke on the condition of anonymity in line with Israeli military rules. Between the drones and ballistic missiles, he estimated that over 1,000 projectiles have been fired from Iran since Friday, with a few dozen making impact in Israel.Pentagon expands Middle East response as Israel, Iran trade strikesReturn to menuThe Pentagon is expanding its military presence in the Middle East and Europe in response to worsening hostilities between Israel and Iran, U.S. officials said Monday, sending refueling planes and an additional aircraft carrier among the resources dispatched.This is an excerpt from a full story.Trump says he is seeking a ‘real end’ to Israel-Iran conflict, ‘not a ceasefire’Return to menuBEIRUT — President Donald Trump wants a “real end” to the Israel-Iran crisis rather than a ceasefire, he told reporters aboard Air Force One early Tuesday, as he returned from the Group of Seven summit in Canada early because he said he wanted to be “on the scene” to deal with the escalating violence in the Middle East.Return to menuKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said that Russian President Vladimir Putin is ready to play a mediation role in the conflict, though “at the moment we see reluctance on the part of Israel, at the very least, to use any mediation services and to enter the peaceful settlement track at all.” He warned that the conflict with Iran was “on the path of further escalation, galloping escalation. The level of unpredictability is absolute.”Iran attacked Israel with about 30 missiles Tuesday morning, IDF saysReturn to menuIsrael said around 30 missiles were launched from Iran toward its territory early Tuesday, on the fifth day of fighting between the two countries.Return to menuIsrael’s military claimed Tuesday to have killed Ali Shadmani, whom it described as Iran’s wartime chief of staff. Israel did not present evidence of the assassination, and Iran did not immediately confirm his death. Iran’s supreme leader appointed Shadmani to his position four days ago after his predecessor, Gholam Ali Rashid, was killed in Israeli attacks on Friday. Rashid was responsible for coordinating operations among Iran’s military forces, according to state media.If confirmed, the assassination would bear resemblance to Israel’s military tactics in its war against Hezbollah last year when it killed longtime leader Hasan Nasrallah and then killed his planned successor within days, fomenting internal disorganization.Return to menuMassive lines of traffic filled one of Tehran’s busiest routes, the Karaj-Chalus road, as people rushed to flee the Iranian capital before any possible escalation in the conflict.Video posted on social media June 16 shows long traffic lines in Tehran as the conflict between Israel and Iran escalates. (Video: The Washington Post)Return to menuIn a Monday statement, 20 Arab and Islamic countries — including U.S. allies such as Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates — condemned Israel’s strikes against Iran, particularly those targeting nuclear facilities. The signatories said there should be no weapons of mass destruction in the Middle East and called on all parties to negotiate an end to the crisis.Video: The moment Israeli airstrikes cut into Iranian state TV broadcastReturn to menuAn Iranian state TV live broadcast was interrupted on June 16 as the building was hit by multiple Israeli strikes. (Video: Iran state TV via Reuters)An explosion tore through an Iranian state television studio during a live broadcast Monday, sending a female anchor hurrying for cover as smoke billowed and debris fell through the frame, in footage of the moment shared widely on social media.“That you heard, is the sound of the aggressor against the soil of the homeland, the sound of the aggressor against the sound of truth and right,” she says just as the explosion hits, rattling the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting studio.Return to menuAn Israeli strike on Iran’s national broadcaster on Monday killed two people, semiofficial news agencies Mehr and Tasnim reported Tuesday. Nima Rajabpour, a news editor, and Masoumeh Azimi, an administrative staff member, were killed in the attack, which hit in the middle of a live broadcast. The Israeli military said the state TV building was concealing military infrastructure, a claim that could not be independently verified.Defense secretary says U.S. is ‘postured defensively’ in Middle EastReturn to menuDefense Secretary Pete Hegseth said in a television interview Monday that the United States is “postured defensively” in the Middle East in pursuit of a peace deal with Iran, as Iran and Israel continue to carry out military strikes on one another.Hegseth, speaking on Fox News, said the United States will defend its own interests and it is his job to makes sure that “our people are safe and that we’re strong,” to set the conditions for a deal with Tehran.Return to menuSearch and rescue teams were dispatched to several locations where there were reports that projectiles landed after an Iranian missile barrage Tuesday morning, the Israel Defense Forces said. The Israeli military previously said it struck dozens of targets in western Iran overnight, while Israel’s air force said it intercepted about 30 drones overnight.Trump reverses position, signs G-7 statement on Iran-Israel conflictReturn to menuBANFF, Alberta — President Donald Trump left the Group of Seven summit a day early to attend to the conflict between Israel and Iran, the White House announced Monday, after he called for “a broader de-escalation of hostilities” in the Middle East in a statement with other global leaders.This is an excerpt from a full story.
html:
Sirens and loud explosions could be heard in Tel Aviv on Tuesday night, just hours after President Donald Trump gathered his top security advisers at the White House to discuss the prospect of U.S. involvement in the conflict between Israel and Iran. “He may decide he needs to take further action to end Iranian enrichment,” Vice President JD Vance said in a post Tuesday on X. In posts on social media, Trump demanded “unconditional surrender” from Iran and said that the United States knows where Iran’s supreme leader is but won’t kill him, “at least not for now.”

What else to know on the fifth day of Israel-Iran strikes

Return to menu

  • A U.S. attack on Iran could have major consequences for Donald Trump’s presidency and the region. Trump left the G-7 summit in Canada a day early Monday to decide whether to join Israel in an effort to destroy Iran’s key underground nuclear facilities — or go in a different direction by engaging in last-minute diplomacy with Tehran in a bid to impair its ability to build a nuclear weapon, U.S. officials said. Trump told reporters on Air Force One early Tuesday that he was “looking for better than a ceasefire” and wants “a real end” to Iran’s nuclear program.
  • U.S. officials told The Washington Post late Monday that the Pentagon is expanding its military presence in the Middle East to increase the options available to commanders, should U.S. assets in the region face a direct threat.
  • Iran fired about 30 missiles toward central Israel on Tuesday morning, injuring at least 12 people, according to Israel’s military and emergency services. Tehran claimed it inflicted strategic damage. Nadav Shoshani, a spokesman for the Israel Defense Forces, told The Post that Iran’s overnight attacks were the “least impactful night … since the beginning of this operation.”
  • Iranian media reported explosions and heavy air defense fire in Tehran and explosions in the northwestern city of Tabriz. On Tuesday afternoon, Iran’s military announced attacks against Israel involving hundreds of drones and “new and advanced weapons” that it said will “intensify in the coming hours,” according to statements published by state media.

Live coverage contributors 34

  • Return to menu

    The Israeli air force is conducting strikes on Tehran, the Israeli military announced Tuesday evening. Earlier Tuesday, Israel Defense Forces spokesman Avichay Adraee issued an evacuation warning for District 18 of Tehran.

  • Trump spoke with Netanyahu on Tuesday, White House official says

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump spoke with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu on Tuesday, according to a White House official who was not authorized to speak publicly.

    Trump, who returned to Washington in the morning after leaving the Group of Seven summit in Canada a day early, has spent the day at the White House consulting with his advisers and national security team amid the ongoing exchange of missile fire between Israel and Iran.

  • Return to menu

    Sirens sounded across Israel a second time early Wednesday local time, with the Israel Defense Forces warning again of missiles on their way to Israel from Iran. Loud explosions could be heard in Tel Aviv as the IDF said it was working to intercept the Iranian missiles.

  • Return to menu

    No casualties have been reported after an Iranian strike on Israel early Wednesday local time, said a spokesperson for Magen David Adom, the country’s emergency services.

    Meanwhile, reports of multiple fires around the country had been received by Israel’s Fire and Rescue Authority, said a spokesperson for the organization.

  • In inaugural address, Trump said U.S. measure of success is ‘the wars we never get into’

    Return to menu

    As President Donald Trump weighs U.S. military involvement in Iran, several of his top allies, including conservative pundit Tucker Carlson, have urged Trump to stay out of the war — with some pointing to his promise of being an anti-war president.

    “We will measure our success not only by the battles we win but also by the wars that we end — and perhaps most importantly, the wars we never get into,” Trump said in his inaugural address in January.

  • Return to menu

    Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu called for nothing short of “total victory” in Israel’s conflicts with Hamas and Iran in an interview with Israel’s Channel 14 news. He said a “different Middle East” would emerge from the aftermath.

    Netanyahu said the operation to strike Iran was planned over the past three months and that his directive was to “go after the scientists.”

    “The scientists had to go, because the nuclear program had to go,” he said. “But I also said we must strike the missiles.”

  • Americans, Trump voters oppose military involvement in Iran, poll finds

    Return to menu

    An Economist-YouGov poll released Tuesday found little appetite for U.S. military involvement in fighting between Israel and Iran. A 60 percent majority said the U.S. military should not “get involved in the conflict between Israel and Iran,” while 16 percent said it should get involved and 24 percent were not sure. Among those who voted for Trump in last year’s election, 53 percent opposed military involvement while 19 percent supported it.

  • Return to menu

    The Israeli military warned early Wednesday local time that it had identified missiles inbound from Iran, and called on the public to seek shelter. Sirens and explosions could be heard in Tel Aviv.

  • Israeli officials call destruction of Fordow nuclear site in Iran a key military goal

    Return to menu

    In remarks to Israeli media Tuesday, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu and National Security Adviser Tzachi Hanegbi insisted that the destruction of Iran’s underground nuclear fuel enrichment site, Fordow, is crucial to the country’s military aims.

  • Return to menu

    Majed Al-Ansari, a spokesman for Qatar’s Ministry of Foreign Affairs, condemned the targeting of nuclear and energy facilities in the conflict between Israel and Iran. He warned it would have “significant repercussions and impacts on global energy markets and regional security in general, especially with regard to the waters of the Gulf, on which we depend not only as a source of water in the region, but as a source of global energy.”

    Qatar is among the gulf states trying to de-escalate fighting between Iran and Israel, The Washington Post reported on Monday.

  • Post Reports podcast: A major turning point in the Israel-Iran conflict

    Return to menu

    Podcast episode

    Israel and Iran have been exchanging attacks since Friday, leaving more than 20 people dead in Israel and more than 200 dead in Iran. On today’s episode of Post Reports, reporter Yeganeh Torbati speaks to host Elahe Izadi about why Israel chose this moment to launch strikes against Iran, whether Iran’s government could fall, and whether the U.S. and President Donald Trump will get involved.

  • Trump ‘perfectly within his right’ on Iran actions, Thune says

    Return to menu

    Senate Majority Leader John Thune (R-South Dakota) backed President Donald Trump and his actions toward Iran, saying the president is “perfectly within his authority” as the U.S. military amassed its forces in the Middle East amid ongoing strikes between Israel and Iran.

    “I think he’s perfectly within his right to do what he’s done so far,” Thune told reporters Tuesday when asked whether the Trump administration will need congressional approval to potentially strike Iran.

  • Israel-Iran conflict could last only as long as their missiles hold out

    Return to menu

    The intensity of Iran’s barrages appears to be sharply dropping. After firing more than 150 missiles on the first night of the conflict, Friday, Iran fired a barrage of just 10 on Tuesday afternoon. Even so, Israeli analysts caution that more than half of Iran’s arsenal remains intact, and an unknown quantity of missiles may be hidden in underground depots.

    This is an excerpt from a full story.

  • In photos: Israeli hospital treats patient wounded in Iranian strikes

    Return to menu

    Nardeen Rabi Gharaba, a Palestinian citizen of Israel and an intensive care nurse, treats a critically wounded female patient at Rabin Medical Center in Petah Tikva, Israel, on Tuesday. The woman was injured when an Iranian missile struck a high-rise residential building on Monday.

    The hospital moved 400 beds to a protected underground facility in a parking garage amid ongoing strikes between Israel and Iran.

  • State Department sets up task force to support U.S. citizens in Israel and broader region

    Return to menu

    The State Department announced Tuesday that it had set up a task force to help U.S. citizens in Israel and the broader region impacted by the ongoing conflict with Iran.

    The new task force is primarily designed to provide information to U.S. citizens and diplomatic personnel. Officials said that they did not have any plans for evacuations but did not rule out that they could come at a later point.

  • Return to menu

    Iranian state media told Iranians to delete WhatsApp from their phones, alleging without evidence that WhatsApp was forwarding data to Israel. “We’re concerned these false reports will be an excuse for our services to be blocked at a time when people need them the most,” said WhatsApp in a statement. “We do not provide bulk information to any government.”

  • Return to menu

    The Israeli military launched 60 fighter jets Tuesday aimed at destroying Iranian missile launchers that targeted Israel, Brig. Gen. Effie Defrin, Israel’s military spokesman, said in a media briefing Tuesday night.

    Defrin said that Israeli jets struck Iranian launchers in western Iran.

  • Commercial airspace in Middle East disrupted by Iran-Israel conflict

    Return to menu

    BEIRUT — As Iran and Israel continue to trade fire for the fifth day, several Middle Eastern countries whose airspace lies between the two arch foes have had flights interrupted and citizens put in danger. The affected governments have been left to scramble for ways to stay out of the conflict.

    Both Iran and Israel have used other countries’ airspace to mount attacks on each other. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu boasted Monday that Israel had “paved an aerial highway to Tehran.”

  • Return to menu

    German Chancellor Friedrich Merz expressed gratitude for Israel’s attack on Iran in televised remarks on the sidelines of the G-7 summit Tuesday, saying Israel was doing “the dirty work … for all of us.”

    “We are also affected by this regime,” Merz added. “This mullah regime has brought death and destruction to the world.”

    Merz said Iran’s return to the negotiating table would preclude the need for further military intervention. “If not, then the complete destruction of the Iranian nuclear weapon program is possibly on the table,” he said.

  • Return to menu

    Germany will assist its nationals in leaving Israel if they choose, the German foreign minister said Tuesday. Israel closed its airspace to civilian traffic at the beginning of its strikes against Iran, stranding foreign nationals within Israel and Israeli citizens overseas.

    The U.S. Embassy said Monday it could not directly assist with evacuations, though it did not explicitly urge Americans to leave Israel.

    Israel’s land borders with Jordan and Egypt remain open.

  • Satellite images show damage to petroleum and oil storage tanks in Iran

    Return to menu

    Satellite imagery captured by Planet Labs on Monday shows multiple storage tanks housing petroleum products that were destroyed overnight in Shahran, a neighborhood in the northwest part of Tehran.

    “The aim of this was to cause fuel shortages and power outages,” said Samir Madani, a co-founder of TankerTrackers.com, which tracks and reports shipments and storage of crude oil.

  • Trump: U.S. knows where Iran leader is but won’t kill him, ‘at least not for now’

    Return to menu

    President Donald Trump ratcheted up tensions with Iran on Tuesday, claiming the United States knows the location of the country’s supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, but is not looking to assassinate him — for the time being.

    Trump made the comments in a social media post, one of several in recent hours that marked an increasingly hostile posture toward Iran as Trump weighs a larger U.S. role in the Israel-Iran conflict.

  • Return to menu

    Vice President JD Vance is looking to reassure supporters of President Donald Trump who are skeptical of foreign intervention as the president weighs a larger U.S. role in the Iran-Israel conflict.

    In a lengthy X post, Vance praised Trump for showing “remarkable restraint” so far and suggested his supporters should trust that he will prioritize U.S. interests in whatever he does.

    “He may decide he needs to take further action to end Iranian enrichment,” Vance wrote. “That decision ultimately belongs to the president. And of course, people are right to be worried about foreign entanglement after the last 25 years of idiotic foreign policy.”

  • Return to menu

    After seeing President Donald Trump’s tweet calling for the evacuation of Tehran, one man said he left the city around midday Tuesday.

    The man, who spoke on the condition of anonymity for fear of reprisal, said it was impossible to exchange money electronically or withdraw money from banks. He said merchants raised prices for food and supplies. Gas station lines were incredibly long, and he waited three hours to fill his car up.

  • Return to menu

    Long lines of cars waited at Tehran’s gas stations as the city’s downtown began to empty on Tuesday. The mass departures followed President Donald Trump’s Truth Social post saying that “everyone should immediately evacuate Tehran” in the early hours of the Iranian morning that day.

  • Return to menu

    Only the U.S. has the extremely heavy “bunker-buster” bombs believed capable of penetrating Iran’s most sophisticated nuclear facilities, which are buried under mountains. If President Donald Trump decides to join Israel in attacking Iran, he would draw Washington deeply into a war he has said would be devastating and that he has wanted to avoid. An attack risks splitting his political coalition, since the Republican Party is divided between those who believe in sharply pulling back from international conflicts and hawks who have long warned that Iran is a menace. The U.S. military has been moving equipment to the Middle East that would help facilitate a broader attack.

  • The young Iranian poet who lost her life in an Israeli strike

    Return to menu

    She dreamed of seeing the band Coldplay live in concert. She loved trying new foods and was learning Italian. She wrote poetry constantly and shared it with friends and family. She was so proud of having summited Iran’s highest peak, Mount Damavand, that she made sure to mention that fact to everyone she met.

    She was, as her friends described in phone interviews and text messages this week, as bright and full of life as the sunflowers that she adored.

    Tehran criticized Group of Seven leaders Tuesday for their statement on the fighting between Israel and Iran, saying its language “disregarded” Israeli aggression. Iranian Foreign Ministry spokesman Esmaeil Baqaei said Israeli strikes have killed “hundreds of innocent people” and destroyed public infrastructure and homes. Baqaei described Iranian strikes against Israel as actions taken in self-defense.

  • Families in Tehran feel rising panic amid Israeli strikes

    Soudeh, 29, an accountant in Tehran, said she has a 10-month-old baby and had not been able to sleep from stress amid Israeli strikes.

    At one point she heard a loud blast in her alley. The buildings in her neighborhood are close together, and though her own wasn’t hit, she was worried about another collapsing, she said, speaking on the condition that she be identified only by her first name, for fear of reprisal.

    All doctors and nurses in Iran had their leave canceled and were asked to remain in medical centers, Iran’s semiofficial Mehr news reported Tuesday, in the face of mass casualty incidents it said are resulting from the conflict. Iran said Sunday that Israeli strikes had killed at least 224 people and wounded hundreds of others and has not provided an updated toll since. Human rights groups in the country say the Health Ministry’s numbers are a significant undercount.

    Israel’s military claimed Tuesday to have killed Ali Shadmani, whom it described as Iran’s wartime chief of staff. Israel did not present evidence of the assassination, and Iran did not immediately confirm his death. Iran’s supreme leader appointed Shadmani to his position four days ago after his predecessor, Gholam Ali Rashid, was killed in Israeli attacks on Friday. Rashid was responsible for coordinating operations among Iran’s military forces, according to state media.

    If confirmed, the assassination would bear resemblance to Israel’s military tactics in its war against Hezbollah last year when it killed longtime leader Hasan Nasrallah and then killed his planned successor within days, fomenting internal disorganization.

    “That you heard, is the sound of the aggressor against the soil of the homeland, the sound of the aggressor against the sound of truth and right,” she says just as the explosion hits, rattling the Islamic Republic of Iran Broadcasting studio.

The Israeli military said the state TV building was concealing military infrastructure, a claim that could not be independently verified.
